FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Logan Generating Plant is owned by Logan Generating Company, LP.  Our overall approach to chemical safety and security involves safe equipment design, well-trained employees & qualified contractors, and regular audits and assessments.



Logan operates an electric and steam generating facility.  Pulverized coal is burned in a state-of-the-art boiler, and the steam is used to generate electricity.  



We store an aqueous ammonia solution, which is safer to handle than anhydrous ammonia.  The ammonia solution is used in our air pollution control system to reduce emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx).  Logan has NOx emission rates that are among the lowest for any facility of its kind.



Logan complies with both the federal Risk Management Program (RMP), and the New Jersey Toxic Catastrophe Prevention Act (TCPA) program as well as the New Jersey Discharge Prevention, Containment and Countermeasure (DPCC)program and other environmental health and safety programs. The general accidental release prevention program is incorporated into overall safe plant operation.  The plant is continuously staffed, with designated security personnel, perimeter fencing and controlled access/gate security.  The control room operators have access to real-time process monitor data plant-wide, and can take emergency action remotely (e.g. through remote shut-off valves).  Trained operators perform regular walk-through visual inspections of equipment.  In accordance with company policy, chemical unloading is supervised, and follows written procedures.



Logan has taken several chemical-specific prevention steps to avert any accidental releases of ammonia.  Control room operators remotely monitor the status of the ammonia system.  A loss of ammonia flow would instantly cause an alarm in the control room, where trained operators would take immediate action to correct the problem.  The ammonia storage and handling system undergoes testing and preventative maintenance that meets or exceeds indu

stry standards.  The ammonia storage is located inside a concrete secondary containment structure.  In the event of a catastrophic release, this structure would prevent the spread of aqueous ammonia and slow the evaporation rate.



The aqueous ammonia system has had no spills and no accidents that resulted in injuries, property damage or offsite effects since Logan began operation in 1994.  



Logan Generating has an Emergency Response Plan, which is coordinated with the Logan Township Emergency Coordinator.  Plant workers undergo annual hazardous materials safety training and emergency response training, as well as regular emergency drills.  Training includes an annual ammonia release drill with local responders.  Plant management annually makes concerted efforts to coordinate with local law enforcement, fire and emergency departments and other first responders to ensure an appropriate response to an incident at the facility.  Logan Generating personnel continuously look for ways to improve safety. In the fall of 2018 a new safety relief valve was installed on the storage tank which is of a double-valve design allowing for one valve set to be out of service for maintenance or repairs while keeping the tank in service and protected by the second valve set.  At the time of this writing there are no additional planned changes to improve the safety of the system.
